# Task

You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.



# Special Instructions

None.

Here is how you can solve this problem in Julia using DataFrames package:

```julia
using DataFrames

function audi_filter(df::DataFrame)
    df = filter(row -> row.manufacturer == "audi" && (row.model == "a4" || row.model == "a4 quattro"), df)
    df[:audi_a4_type] = true
    return df
end
```
This function uses the `filter` function from DataFrames package to filter rows that have manufacturer as "audi" and model either as "a4" or "a4 quattro". It then creates a new column `audi_a4_type` with value `true`. Finally, it returns the modified DataFrame.

You can use this function like this:
```julia
df = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "toyota", "bmw", "audi"], model=["a4", "corolla", "x1", "a4 quattro"])
new_df = audi_filter(df)
display(new_df)
```
This will filter the DataFrame to only include rows where manufacturer is "audi" and model is either "a4" or "a4 quattro". It will then create a new column `audi_a4_type` with value `true`. The resulting DataFrame is displayed.
